data.text: Introduction
Lockdown is the process of controlling the movement and access – both entry and exit

– of people (NHS staff, patients and visitors) around a trust site or other specific building/area in response to an identified risk, threat or hazard that might impact on the security of patients, staff and assets or, indeed the capacity of that facility to continue to operate. A lockdown is achieved through a combination of physical security measures and the deployment of security personnel.

Lockdown is considered to be the best means of controlling access to and egress from hospital buildings. It can be used to prevent the escalation of certain types of incident and to reduce the risk of danger to patients, visitors and staff. To be effective a lockdown will need to be declared and implemented quickly and resourced by both hospital and police staff possibly for some time.
The ability to lockdown the hospital is of primary importance in certain types of emergency situation.

This policy and procedure has been developed to ensure that sufficient information is obtained wherever possible to determine whether the threat is a credible one or a malicious hoax and to make clear how staff need to respond.
This policy and procedure may need to be used in conjunction with the Trust's major incident plan.
The decision to lockdown the hospital or part of the hospital will be considered when extraordinary circumstances exist including:
The need to contain or isolate a communicable disease or hazard within the hospital
The presence of a Chemical, Biological, Radiological or Nuclear (CBRN) agent within the hospital which poses a threat to patient's visitors or staff.
A threat to patients, visitors or staff within the hospital from terrorist or other potentially relevant activity outside it.
A requirement to reinforce the safety of a patient, visitor or member of staff from serious or immediate threat.
It is important to note that in locking down a trust there are three key elements:
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

A lockdown may be implemented as part of the Trust's Major Incident Plan. However; there may be occasions when local managers will need to achieve a lockdown, for example in the event of a patient going AWOL, or to secure an area for other reasons e.g. presentation of a violent or aggressive person; or a suspect package.
It is important to remember that many sites/buildings have multi-occupancy arrangements and these must fit with the high level lockdown plan.

This guidance relates to all employees within Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust and will supersede all other relevant guidance held by individuals who may have transferred into the Trust from other NHS organisations or from another Trust site.

Experience has shown that during a wide range of incidents, health services are vulnerable. Contamination, infection or even the sheer pressure of the ensuing numbers of people seeking care can threaten services to the point of collapse. Therefore locking down an NHS site or NHS building may be a proportionate response from a variety of threats and hazards to safeguard patients, staff, visitors, and protect NHS assets. In accordance with this, the policy contains clearly outlined principles that can be followed to lock down all or parts of a site or building in a wide range of scenarios.
Definitions

table_items.text: CBRNE is an acronym for chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear and explosives.
Critical assets can be people, property, services or other assets located within buildings/ premises that the Trust consider a high priority to protect

Lockdown is the process of controlling the movement and access – both entry and exit – of people (NHS staff, patients and visitors) around the trust site or other specific trust building/area in response to an identified risk, threat or hazard that might impact upon the security of patients, staff and assets or indeed the capacity of that facility to continue to operate. A lockdown is achieved through combination of physical security measures and the deployment of proficient personnel.

An assessment of the lockdown capability of a building or site (or parts thereof). The Lockdown Profile will conclude either “Adequate lockdown capability‟, or „Additional resources are needed‟. If additional resources are needed a plan for addressing those needs must be prepared and acted upon

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Committee responsibilities

4.1.1 The emergency preparedness and business continuity committees on each site will monitor arrangements and performance in relation to Lockdown. This group is a sub- group of the Governance Quality and Risk Committee

4.1.2 The role of the business continuity and emergency planning committee is to ensure that the Trust has business continuity and emergency plans in place, and robust business continuity and emergency preparedness, resilience and response management system, validate plans and policies in line with national Guidelines and Standards.
Chief Executive / Managing Director

The Chief Executive or Managing Director, as accounting officer has overall responsibility for the safety of Trust premises, patients, visitors and staff. The Chief Executive has delegated the executive lead for security and Business Continuity planning to the Director of Operations.
Director of Operations
The Director of Operations is accountable for ensuring that there are robust measures in place to ensure the security of the Trust. Their responsibility also includes:
Ensuring that the aims and objectives of this guidance and procedures are met.
Ensuring that adequate resources are made available.
Ensuring that any processes in place for management of a lockdown is reviewed by relevant managers.
Director on Call

Out of normal working hours the MSE Executive or site Director on- Call, will be responsible for authorising and initiating any immediate lockdown and instigate the Major Incident plan if appropriate (refer to action card in appendix 4).
Estates Site Manager

The Estates Site Manager will lead on issues relating to functionality of buildings and building resilience. They will have an in-depth knowledge of the structure and various systems that operate within any building and their knowledge will be invaluable when determining whether it is possible to achieve a full or partial lockdown.
Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS)

The Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS) is responsible for ensuring that all Trust security personnel are aware of the actions to be taken in response to a lockdown and is responsible for providing support on all aspects of the Trusts security, capabilities and functionality of security arrangements. See action card in appendix G.
The Trust Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS) will co-ordinate the deployment of Security/Porters/Lockdown Marshalls for lockdown procedures.
On request by the Site Director on Call, the MSE Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS) will instigate a full or partial lockdown of doors.

In order to assist with the lockdown Security Staff will monitor entrances via CCTV and communicate by radio to the LSMS and/or Site Director on Call any observations appertaining to security concerns. Particular emphasis will be given to designated entrance and egress points to ensure that these areas are prioritised.
The LSMS is responsible for providing information on all aspects of trust security and ensuring the capability and functionality of security arrangements.
The LSMS is responsible for:
Providing guidance over the characteristics that will influence the ability of any site to effectively lock down, and the resources required to do so.
Assist in the development of a lockdown risk profile, taking into account local circumstances.
Assist in undertaking a lockdown.
Supporting inter-agency collaboration (see below)
The LSMS will also be responsible for maintaining relationships with external agencies which will include:
The Police, who will be able to inform on local threats and hazards. They will also be able to estimate the level of support they can provide during a lockdown.
Representatives from the ambulance and patient transport services to identify if and how lockdown will affect their work.
Security/Lockdown Marshalls/Portering Staff

The Security/Lockdown Marshalls/Portering staff will respond in accordance with their action card on the request of trust management to lock down Trust buildings to the required level dependent on the type of threat or hazard.

The doors which are not able to be locked will have dedicated staff allocated to each area with keys to manually lockdown that specific area. Keys will be signed out from the Security Office by designated staff. They will be responsible for return of keys on completion of the task.
Senior Manager on Call/ Clinical Site Manager

Authority to call a lockdown and/or declare a stand down can be delegated to the Clinical Site Manager or the On-Call Senior Manager. This is because there may be occasions when the site manager has to make a dynamic assessment of the situation. In such cases, the senior manager on-call must be notified as soon as practicable.

The Site Manager or Senior Manager On-Call is also responsible for ensuring the Chief Executive / Managing Director, Site Director or Director on-call, and the Head of Communications are informed of the lockdown situation. This will enable a major incident to be declared, and ensure that appropriate support and assistance is provided to the affected site or area.
Service Managers / Team / Ward / Departmental Managers Responsibility
Service Managers working with their teams, Estates representatives, the Fire Officer
and the LSMS to, identify and document the critical assets within the site and complete the Lockdown Toolkit. This will support the following:
Determine if a lockdown (or partial lockdown) is achievable.
Identify appropriate resources to undertake a lockdown.
Share details of the agreed lockdown plan with their teams to ensure that if, or when implemented, all staff are aware of their roles and responsibilities.
Maintain the lockdown plan aligned with the local Major Incident Plan/Business Continuity Plans and forward a copy to the Document Control Manager.
That plans are tested for robustness and appropriate amendments or revisions are cascaded.
Identify local stakeholders and ensure they are consulted when developing the local lockdown procedure.
Ensure that any change to the site/building will instigate a review of the lockdown procedure.
Ensure that all staff are fully aware of their lockdown roles and responsibilities.
Ensure staff are fully trained to undertake their role during lockdown
Switchboard Operator
The switchboard operator will implement either the internal or external lockdown action card and ensure immediate contact is made with the following:
In Hours:
Director on-call (Tactical Commander)
Senior Manager on-call (Operations Commander)
Local security Management Specialist (LSMS)
Head of Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response (EPRR)
Out of Hours
Clinical Site Manager who will decide on the level of response.
Head of Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response (EPRR)

The role of the Head of Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response (EPRR) is to oversee the preparation and planning and response to a major incident including a lockdown incident and ensure ongoing business continuity in the event of a lockdown.
Fire Officer
The Fire Officer will provide advice on fire safety and the operation and functionality of fire doors. Liaison with the local fire service may also be necessary at this point.
Estates Department

The Estates Department will lead on issues relating to the functionality of buildings and building resilience. They will have an in-depth knowledge of the structure and various systems that operate within any building and their knowledge will be important when determining whether it is possible to achieve a full or partial lockdown.
Media/Communications staff

The Head of Communications/Communications team will help to ensure that a controlled message is given to staff, patients and visitors within the trust and to external stakeholders as well. The local media can be helpful in directing people away from the site or building. The communications team will be able to seek their assistance, so it is important that they are involved and kept up to date with the situation. See action card in appendix H.
All Managers and Staff

All managers and staff have a responsibility to take reasonable care of their own safety and security, as well as the safety and security of patients and visitors and to participate as required in the event of the implementation of a lockdown. In order to support the lockdown, staff are likely to be asked to carry out activities that are outside of their normal job description. No member of staff should be asked to undertake any duties that will place themselves or others at risk unduly.
All visitors should be requested to follow directions to support the lockdown. However it is noted that the containment of any person against their will is prohibited.
Legislation

The ability of Primary Care Trusts, NHS Acute Trusts and Foundation Trusts to lock down their site or buildings fits in with their statutory responsibilities as category 1 responders as defined by the Civil Contingencies Act 2004. The act states that category 1 responders must assess the risks of emergencies occurring and have plans in place to manage them. Locking down a trust site or building may be the most suitable response in a wide range of emergencies. A lockdown will also support other major incident responses – for example, the evacuation of a hospital.

The consequences of instigating a proportionate lockdown and the short, medium and long-term effect it may have on NHS services must be considered by Trust management. Their decision to lock down must be underpinned by the legal reasons for doing so.

Because healthcare sites and buildings are usually open to the public, members of the public have an implied licence to enter them. However, the owner of any such premises has a right to refuse access to any of these premises. In this instance, if someone other than the owner (or a tenant or a licensee) enters the premises having been advised not to, or is already on the premises and refuses to leave, they may be considered a trespasser and reasonable force may be used to prevent access or to remove them. If an individual enters the locked down premises or refuses to leave, they could be prosecuted under criminal law.

If a casualty or a patient attends a locked down healthcare site or building, staff implementing the lockdown should explain that although the casualty or patient requires treatment, it will be in their best interest to receive treatment at other, safer, healthcare premises. Consequently, their ‘right to treatment' under the Human Rights Act 1998 will not be infringed upon.

In the absence of the police, who are able to enforce a containment cordon, it will only be lawful for an NHS trust to prevent exit of a significant number of people from its premises by utilising specific legislative provision (e.g. emergency regulations under the Civil Contingencies Act and/or Public Health England Health Protection Legislation 2010 which provides protection of the public from notifiable diseases. Even when these specific regulations can be used, specific tenets of the Human Rights Act 1998 must be considered – for example, a person's right to liberty (Article 5) and an individual's right to respect for private and family life (Article 8). Without these regulations, it is likely that exit could only be prevented in relation to specific individuals in certain circumstances,
which are likely to be limited to the following situations:
The individual is committing an offence or causing injury or damage to property which may lead to them being arrested.
They are detained under the Mental Health Act or otherwise lawfully detained.

While NHS staff can give direction within their premises (for example, stating which exit someone can use), it is unlawful to forcibly prevent exit from NHS premises unless it is for the reasons stated above. Without these justifications, NHS staff could be open to legal action under the criminal and/or civil law if they prevented a person from leaving.

Nonetheless, there may be circumstances when a lockdown which prevents individuals from exiting NHS premises (or part of them) is desirable. If this occurs, NHS staff can only appeal to individuals to stay in the site and/or building identified for lockdown. If individuals choose to exit, a safe route must be available for them to do so.

Relevant legislation in relation to fire doors is the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety order 2005, which applies to ‘any place', including any workplace. Trusts are not exempt from the order, which imposes requirements on the ‘responsible person' – who, in a trust will be the employer. Under Article 14(2), the responsible person must ensure that routes to emergency exits from premises and the exits themselves are kept clear at all times. In the event of a lockdown, fire escapes that are locked to prevent individuals from exiting the premises may constitute a breach of the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005.
Rights of access and egress

5.9.1 NHS Trusts have the right to refuse access – patients/ casualties attending a locked down premises may be subject to the “doctrine of best interest‟ and treatment elsewhere may be considered more appropriate thus not infringing on Right to Treatment under the Human Rights Act 1998. If someone enters the premises having been advised not to, or is already in the premises but refuses to leave, they may be considered a trespasser and reasonable force may be used to prevent access or remove them. If an individual enters a locked down premises or refuses to leave, they could be prosecuted under criminal law.

5.9.2 The right to refuse exit is more complex - if the police are not present  and enforcing a containment cordon it is only lawful for NHS to prevent exit of a “significant number‟ of people under special circumstances, e.g. containment of a communicable disease under specific sections of Civil Contingencies Act / Public Health Act.

5.9.3 Exit of individuals can only be prevented if relevant sections of the Mental Health Act apply, or if by leaving, the person is committing a criminal offence, or causing injury to property leading to arrest.

5.9.4 NHS staff can only appeal to people to stay inside a locked down area, but if they choose to leave, a safe route must be available for them to do so. It is unlawful to prevent exit from NHS premises unless it is for reasons given above.
Potential threats and hazards to NHS trusts
Consideration must be given to the full spectrum of potential threats and hazards. For the purpose of this document, a threat and hazard are as follows:
Threat – a malicious event instigated by an individual or group which has the potential to cause loss or damage to an asset. This could include technological accidents or terrorists attack.
Hazard – source of potential danger or adverse conditions. This could include natural hazards (flooding, storm, tornado, and hurricane).
To develop a lockdown threat and hazard assessment, a wide range of threats and hazards should be considered. Potential threats and hazards are suggested below:

table_items.text: Malicious threats to buildings and estates
Violence against staff, patients and visitors
Theft of hospital assets and personal property
Abuse against staff, patients and visitors
Adulteration of clinical supplies and products

Planning a lockdown
A lockdown is achieved through a combination of physical security measures and the deployment of security personnel and/or lockdown Marshalls.
There are three key elements that are crucial to locking down the Trust or part of the Trust:
Preventing Entry
Preventing Exit
Preventing/restricting movement of people
The fundamental purpose of one or a combination of the above is to either exclude or contain staff, patients and visitors.
The lockdown plan can be applied to achieve partial, progressive or full lockdown.
Trust lockdown risk profile
In order to implement a lockdown a risk assessment must be completed for each identified site, building, or area of the organisation

The risk profile will review a number of areas, including: critical assets, hazards, building arrangements and personnel in order to conclude whether the site has adequate capability to lockdown, or if additional resources are needed.
The following should be considered when considering implementing a lockdown of a MSEFT building or area:

A lockdown should be used to ensure the safety and security of all MSEFT personal, patients, property and assets in the event of a major incident, and by doing so will protect the integrity of the NHS.
There are three key elements to a lockdown – Preventing entry to a specific site, preventing exit from a specific site and preventing movement in a specific site.
There are also different levels of lockdown. Please see section 9 which provides
details on each level of lockdown that can be implemented.
NB. Please also see the risk assessment lockdown matrix in appendix A.
Levels of lockdown

a) Full/Total Lockdown: This is the highest level and includes facility and perimeter security. A full lockdown is the process of preventing freedom of entry to and exit from either an entire NHS site or from a specific trust building. During a full lockdown, ALL perimeter doors are secured and NO ONE is allowed to enter or exit the facility. Security personnel or other designated personnel such as lockdown Marshalls will be assigned to key entrance/exit points.

b) Partial Lockdown: A partial lockdown can be defined in a number of ways. In most instances, a partial lockdown is the locking down of a specific part of a trust site or a specific building or part of a building.

c) Portable Lockdown: A partial lockdown which may have been originally ‘static' in nature may evolve into a portable lockdown. A portable lockdown is when an ongoing lockdown is moved from one location on a trust site to another.
d) Progressive Lockdown: A progressive lockdown can also be called an incremental lockdown, and can be a step-by-step lockdown of a trust site or building in repose to an escalating scenario.
e) Controlled Lockdown: Type 1 – Controlled Lockdown/Exit only: During a controlled lockdown/exit only.
ALL perimeter doors are secured. Security personnel/ lockdown Marshalls are
assigned to ALL perimeter doors. Each person attempting to leave would be screened, as defined by this policy.

Type 2 – Controlled Lockdown/Entry Only: During a controlled lockdown/entry only, ALL perimeter doors are secured. Security personnel/ lockdown Marshalls are assigned to these doors. Each person attempting to enter would be screened, as defined by this policy, by security staff.

Type 3 – Controlled Lockdown with Entry/Exit. During a controlled lockdown with entry/exit. ALL perimeter doors are secured and security personnel/ lockdown Marshalls are assigned to ALL entry/exits. Each person attempting to enter or exit would be screened in accordance to this policy.

Type 4 – Partial Lockdown: During a partial lockdown, ALL foot traffic is directed towards pre-designated controlled entrances/exits (Main entrance, Emergency department, out patients). Security or lockdown Marshalls will maintain control at these locations. Each person attempting to enter or exit would be screened in accordance to this policy.

Type 5 – Emergency Department Lockdown: This type of lockdown is used to regulate entry/exit to the Emergency Department only. All doors and lifts to and from the Emergency Department will be secured. Security personnel and /or lockdown Marshalls will be assigned to these areas. The Emergency Department Consultant or Director On-call or the Incident Commander would make the decision to lockdown the Emergency Department.

It is important to note that, regardless of the nature of the lockdown or whether it is full, partial or progressive, the broad objective is always the same. A lockdown should be used to ensure the safety and security of staff, patients, public, property and assets.
Declaration of hospital lockdown

The declaration will be made Director level or following a request from a Police Incident Officer. The declaration will be made after taking relevant clinical advice and, in the case of criminal activity, the police. Where a decision needs to be made quickly and consultation would delay the implementation thereby posing a threat to the safety of patients visitors or staff a decision to lockdown can be made without consultation. The Trust Incident Control Team (Silver Command) / Director on-call should be made fully aware of the reasons behind the decision and a Strategic Management Team (SMT) (Gold Command) meeting convened to discuss the implications. It may be prudent at this stage to declare a hospital ‘critical incident' and implement the Trust major incident procedures and business continuity arrangements to ensure continued patient care.
Lockdown activation
As soon as a lockdown has been declared, security staff should report to the security office and be allocated:
Action card
Map if appropriate
Keys
Two-way radio
Appropriate visual clothing / personal protection equipment
A security officer should remain at the car park entrance to prevent entry should it be required.
Hospital entrances:

NB: Radio contact at all times constant checks on all areas. Radio use only for the Lockdown and for control to contact us.
Lockdown procedures will be put in place using the following principles:
Selected hospital entrances will be put on “lock down” with physically staffed security and lockdown personnel.
All visitors will be denied access into the hospital to minimise cross- contamination and the spread of disease.
Visitors currently in the building will be instructed on the actions they need to take.
A Family and Friends reception area will be set up in the Education Centre. Reception areas will be made ready by Education Centre staff and the Chaplin's.

Visitors picking up family members or discharged patients will be directed to the Family and Friends reception area in the Education Centre. If safe to do so, a discharged patient will be taken by a member of staff to the Family and Friends reception centre in the Education Centre.
Only essential employees (employees who have not been asked to stay at home) will be allowed access but must be in possession of their ID badge.
Lockdown deployment
Security Officers will be deployed to designated areas in response to the lockdown, and procedures will be put in place using the following principles:
Selected hospital entrances / corridor will be put on ‘lockdown' and physically staffed by security personnel /or lockdown marshals.
All visitors will be denied access to the lockdown area or Trust site dependent on reason for lockdown
Visitors currently in the building will be instructed on actions they need to take
Visitors picking up family or friends will be directed to the designated safe exit
Only staff with Trust photo identification badge will be permitted to access the Trust, and will be informed of areas that are not accessible due to the lockdown and actions that need to be taken.
Staff deployment

The Trust only has limited security personnel on site. The arrangements for securing an area will therefore depend on the availability of additional staff trained as lockdown Marshalls who are present at the time.

As soon as lockdown staff has been briefed on the incident details and they have been issued with a High Vis tabard and radio, they will need to go as quickly as possible to fulfil their roles. Action must be taken as quickly to secure the building. Any access controls should be utilised to speed up the process. A manual lockdown should be undertaken as quickly as possible.

To speed up a manual lockdown, careful consideration needs to be given to the order in which doors and windows will be locked. Senior staff should decide this based on the high risk areas within  their area, their use and accessibility to the public.

Ward staff will be responsible for controlling the movement of patients/visitors within their ward areas. Where possible, Porters / Lockdown Marshalls will be positioned at main access points to explain the situation to people and request their co- operation.
Staff should remain calm and professional during the deployment in order to keep visitors and patients calm.

Once staff are in control of their areas they should communicate this to the Security Office or the senior manager in the Incident Control room. Communication links should be maintained at all times so that staff can be updated on the progress of the lockdown.
Screening
Individuals will be question/screen individuals upon entry/exit of the building. A check of the following will take place:
Trust Identification Cards
The purpose of the visit
Their destination
Individuals name /company name and check of ID.
The destination they have travelled from.
It may be necessary in some incidents to inspect bags, packages and vehicles. All screening must be documented fully including vehicle registration numbers and location.
If any answers to the questions outlined above cause concern a Senior

Manager should be summoned immediately. No person should be allowed to enter or exit an area that has been locked down unless they are able to provide satisfactory answers to these questions. Those exiting Trust site or its buildings will be directed to the safest exit point.
Crowd management and control

Members of the public involved in a lockdown situation may feel anxious when they are either contained within or excluded from a site/building. Such feelings may be increased by the nature of the lockdown, e.g. a CBRN incident. It is likely that public cooperation will be proportionate to the circumstances of the lockdown and their perception of the risk to themselves.

It is recommended that staff be given advice on appropriate phrases to be used in a lockdown situation to provide information to the public. For example, in the case where an agitated individual wishes to leave a site or building under lockdown and this may put that individual or others at risk, an appropriate phrase such as “For your own safety, you should stay on site/in the building” may be appropriate.

There may be circumstances when a lockdown can be breached. A breach of a lockdown is more likely to occur when anxious members of the public demand to leave a locked down site/building. As indicated above, legally it is not possible to stop them (See Section 5.0). In this situation, staff should consider identifying a secure route out of the site or building that leads to a specific exit with robust security measures in place.
Lockdown stand-down

It will be the responsibility of the Hospital Incident Control Centre either at the conclusion of the incident or following advice from the Police Incident Officer to declare a stand-down. The procedure for the subsequent stand-down will then depend on the nature of the lockdown.

The loss of acute facilities will have a serious effect on healthcare provisions for the Trust and must be reviewed and prioritised throughout. The Police will review the need if any for a criminal case to be instigated against individuals and will make judgements in discussion with the Managing Director and / or nominated Deputy. In cases involving terrorism it may be that the buildings themselves become a ‘scene of crime' and will not be released for some time.
That decision must be provided from the Police as soon as possible to allow the implementation of business continuity arrangements and use of mutual aid with other Trusts when release is delayed.

When the stand-down for the lockdown procedures has been declared by the Hospital Incident Control Centre and can be undertaken, the Local Security Management Specialist or Security Manager will initiate the following message to the Trust Security Personnel via the two-way radio system:
This message is to be repeated 3 times “Emergency Lockdown all Clear”.

All key personnel will be asked to assemble in the Hospital Control Centre in order to take part in a hot debrief led by the Local Security Management Specialist / Security Manager and the Emergency Planning and Liaison Officer.

All paperwork relating to the incident must be retained no matter how insignificant it might seem, post-it notes, rough drafts etc. This information will be used in compiling a post incident report with timeline.
Communications
Emergency two way radios

17.1.1 The Trust has a number of two way radios which are available during a major incident and are kept fully charged at all times. The radios are available via Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response leads.
17.1.2 These will be distributed on the instructions of Silver Command and a record will be kept of who they have been allocated to.
17.1.3 The emergency channel should be nominated with call signs preceded by Hotel. The person designated as being in overall charge of the incident will use the call sign Hotel
Training requirements

Lockdown and scenario based training will be given to all security staff and lead Portering staff. The lockdown training will be delivered by the Local Security Management Specialist/Security Manager in conjunction with Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response (EPRR) leads.

Security and portering staff should also engage with Project Griffin lead by attend the National Counter Terrorism Security Office, exploring ways to aid the Trust in preventing, handling and recovering from a terrorist attack.
Monitoring and audit
This policy will be reviewed every three years or in accordance with the following on an as when required basis:
Legislative changes
Good practice guidance
Case law
Significant incidents reported
New vulnerabilities
Changes to organisational infrastructure

Appendix 14: Orsett Hospital - procedures to implement lockdown of hospital premises
The ability to lockdown Orsett hospital is of primary importance in an emergency situation.

This procedure has been developed to ensure that sufficient information is obtained wherever possible to determine whether the threat is a credible one or a malicious hoax and also that staff know how to respond.
This procedure may need to be used in conjunction with the Trust's major incident plan.
The  decision  to  lockdown  Orsett  hospital  or  part  of  Orsett  hospital  will  be considered when extraordinary circumstances exist including:
Containment of communicable disease within the hospital
The presence of a CBRN agent circulating with the hospital which poses a threat to patients
The treat to patients within the hospital from terrorist activity outwith.
Requirement to reinforce the safety of a VIP or other patient from serious criminal activity.
Levels and types of Lockdown

Type – Controlled Lockdown/Exit only: During a controlled lockdown/exit only. ALL perimeter doors are secured. Security personnel/designees are assigned to ALL perimeter doors. Each person attempting to leave would be screened, as defined by this policy.

Type – Controlled Lockdown/Entry Only: During a controlled lockdown/entry only, ALL perimeter doors are secured. Security personnel/designees are assigned to these doors. Each person  attempting  to  enter  would  be  screened,  as defined by this policy, by security staff.

Type 3 – Controlled Lockdown with Entry/Exit. During a controlled lockdown with entry/exit. ALL perimeter doors are secured and security personnel/designees are assigned to ALL entry/exits. Each  person attempting to enter or exit would be screened in accordance to this policy.

Type   –  Minor  Injuries  Unit  Lockdown:   This type  of lockdown  is  used  to regulate entry/exit to Minor Injuries Unit only. All doors and elevators to and from the Minor Injuries Unit will be secured. Security personnel and /or designees will be assigned to these areas. The Minor Injuries senior person on duty On-call or the Incident  Commander  would  make  the  decision  to  lockdown  the  Minor  Injuries department.
Initiation of Lockdown procedures:
As soon as a lockdown has been called, the security officer should urgently contact the site manager via switchboard.

data.text: Lockdown procedures will be put in place using the following principles:
Selected hospital entrances will be put on “lock down” with the main entrance by Phlebotomy being the only point of entry/exit. This will be physically staffed by the security person.
All  visitors  will  be  denied  access  into  the  hospital  to  minimise  cross- contamination and the spread of disease.
Visitors currently in the building will be instructed on the actions they need to take.

Visitors picking up family members or patients will be directed to the main entrance by Phlebotomy where a Family and Friends reception area will be set up. Exits from this area shall be barrier by security/porter
Only essential employees (employees who have not been asked to stay at home) will be allowed access but must be in procession of their ID badge.
Command and Control
The Orsett site manager will oversee site operations, ensure communication links and effective cascade. Act as a liaison point between all levels of the command and control and the site.
Incident Control Team - (SILVER)

The Incident Control Team will co-ordinate actions at a tactical level. The Incident Control Team's base initially will be the training room, upper corridor Orsett Hospital unless this is inaccessible in which case an alternative should be found. The Incident Control Team will:-
Co-ordinate frontline management of the plan
Co-ordination of the operational services to ensure business continuity to ensure essential core services are maintained
Make an accurate assessment of the impact of the situation and its likely duration
Identifying and communicating with the necessary personnel to form an Operational Continuity team or teams;
Ensuring that all wards and departments have invoked their Contingency Plans
Remain in operation until normal operations are resumed.
Prioritising the work of the teams according to need.
Keep Trust senior management informed of progress as appropriate.
Ensure the safety of staff, patients & visitors on site
Act as the main point of contact with external organisations.
Ensure that the Strategic Management Team is kept fully up to date and given sufficient information on which to base decisions
Operationalise Strategic Management Team instructions
Direct and support local teams
Conduct a full debrief of the incident following its conclusion so that lessons can be learned for subsequent events.
The Incident Control Team (Silver) will be made up from the following members:-
Site manager
Senior staff from all areas
Clinicians on site,
Any other appropriate staff depending on the nature of the incident and called by the site manager.
The Strategic Management Team (GOLD) will be set up at Basildon hospital and will directly liaise with the Orsett Site Manager.
